newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian Oil GDR seen hit by political woes.
newsitem.headline: Indian Oil GDR seen hit by political woes.

text.p: India's political crisis will hit a keenly-awaited $350 million issue of global equity by the country's largest refiner, Indian Oil Corporation (IOC), as crucial reforms are put on hold, analysts said on Thursday.

"The Indian government will need to address two key issues before IOC can tap the GDR market -- settlement of oil pool dues and a reforms agenda for the downstream oil industry," said analyst Avadhoot Sabnis at securities firm James Capel B&K.
"Given the current political scenario, no action is likely in the immediate future, and the GDR looks delayed until the third quarter of 1997/98," Sabnis said in a note to investors.
India was plunged into political chaos on Sunday when the Congress party withdrew crucial support for the ruling coalition.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda, who heads the 10-month-old United Front government, is due to face a vote of confidence in parliament on April 11.
"The government is not taking a decision on the price hike. Unless you do that you cannot launch the issue," said Jaspal Bindra, head of corporate finance at UBS Securities.
Analysts say an oil price hike is unavoidable to reduce the oil pool deficit, a subsidy the government pays oil firms to compensate them for selling oil in the domestic market below global prices.
The oil pool deficit is currently estimated to total around 158 billion rupees ($4.4 billion).

Analysts said IOC's issue -- which was due to be launched soon after last month's jumbo offering by the state-run Videsh Sanchar Nigam Ltd -- would be the only significant casualty of the government's ambitious divestment plan.
"If things settle down and the budget gets passed I don't see the divestment programme taking a hit," Bindra said.
"It all depends on how quickly the political crisis gets resolved. The only one to suffer immediately will be IOC."

India plans to raise $1.3 billion in 1997/98 (April-March) by selling shares in state-run firms including IOC, Gas Authority of India, Modern Food Industries and India Tourism Development Corporation.

"From a policy perspective, the one near-term issue which will be affected is that the petroleum price hike will be delayed," said Arup Raha, senior economist at U.S. investment bank Lehman Brothers in Hong Kong.
Raha said it was unlikely that the country's economic reforms programme which marked India's gradual conversion to a free-market economy would be affected.
"The current situation is more of a conflict between personalities rather than policies," he said.
"If you take a step back and look at the overall picture, regardless of which party comes to power, the economic agenda is set."
